Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopic and Microscopic Studies of Surface Reaction Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration: In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Michael Trenary and his students in the Department of Chemistry of the University of Illinois at Chicago are conducting fundamental experimental studies of reactions on transition metal surfaces that are designed to not only establish the mechanistic details of the reactions studied, but also to reveal more general reactivity trends in surface chemistry and heterogeneous catalysis. This work entails the characterization of surface intermediates with reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS) combined with studies on the structure and spatial distribution of the same surface species with variable temperature scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM). The spectral and spatial information from the experiments will be complemented by density functional theory calculations performed through collaborations with theoreticians. The insights gained from this research will provide a basis for the design of better catalysts and better catalytic processes. All of the research is being done in the context of training students at the graduate, undergraduate, and postdoctoral level in modern methods of experimental surface science. This training will prepare these students for a variety of jobs in technology-based industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established important new insights into the mechanisms of chemical reactions that take place on transition metal surfaces while at the same time provided intense training of students in advanced research methods using sophisticated and unique scientific instruments. The surface chemistry of transitional metals is important as it underlies the use of these metals as catalysts for a large variety of processes from the efficient manufacture of valuable chemical products, to the remediation of environmental pollutants, to the development of new technologies in the area of renewable energy. The research specifically focused on utilizing two advanced techniques that provide complementary information on the identity, interactions, and reactions of small molecules on metal surfaces of direct relevance to catalysis. The first technique is infrared spectroscopy, which has the sensitivity and resolution to detect and distinguish between different molecular species as they undergo reactions on surfaces. The second technique is low temperature scanning tunneling microscopy, which allows individual molecules and the way they are arranged on surfaces to be observed. From these observations, the influence of the spatial arrangements of molecules on the chemical reactions that they can undergo on surfaces can be determined.  As one example, infrared spectroscopy was used to establish new details of the ammonia oxidation reaction on a platinum surface. This reaction is of importance in the industrial production of nitric acid using platinum catalysts. More significantly, the infrared studies led to the development of a way to prepare a platinum surface covered with nitrogen atoms and only with nitrogen atoms, which then permitted the study of the chemical properties of surface nitrogen in such catalytic processes as the removal of poisonous nitric oxide from automobile exhaust by catalytic converters. Microscopy was then used to observe and characterize the two-dimensional structure of individual nitrogen atoms on a platinum surface and how they react with hydrogen to form the NH species. This is the first hydrogenation step in the production of ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen, which because of its wide spread use as a fertilizer makes ammonia one of the most important commodity chemicals produced through catalysis. The combination of spectroscopic and microscopic techniques provided a great deal of new information on the way the spatial arrangements of the nitrogen atom reactant and NH molecule product influence the overall reaction mechanism. Such new information is urgently needed in order to develop new, better, and less expensive catalysts for a variety of important processes.
